articles.title: about
articles.contents: This site was made with distill, tables scraped from googlesheets measures, and dontpanic, using googlesheets:: and cleaned with the tidyverse::.

articles.title: dontpanic
articles.contents:
Contents
keybindings
commands



library(tidyverse)
library(kableExtra)

keybindings <- read_rds("data/keybindings.rds")
commands <- read_rds("data/commands.rds")



keybindings


context_kb <- keybindings %>% pluck("context") %>% table()


keybindings %>%
  arrange(context) %>% 
  kable() %>% 
  kable_styling() %>% 
  group_rows(index = setNames(context_kb,
                              names(context_kb)))

shows a screenful and stops; go one screen forward with spacebar and back with b, q to exit

sends to; i.e., can print to a file. differs from >> in that overwrites

the echo command prints text


NA


bash

appends; rather than overwrites as > does


NA


bash

pipe sends left of | to command on right


NA


bash


cut


removes sections of each line in a file; cut expects lines to be tab separator. -d option to specify delimiter -f to select a field (column)


NA


bash


uniq


filters adjacent matching lines in a file; use -c for count


NA


bash


for thing in list_of_things do operation_using $thing # Indentation within the loop is not required, but aids legibility done

articles.title: Untitled
articles.description: A new article created using the Distill format.
articles.contents:
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing, native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill for R Markdown at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.

articles.title: tasks

library(tidyverse) 
library(kableExtra)
library(dontpanic)

tasks <- read_rds("data/tasks.rds") 



categories


categories <- tasks %>% pluck("c") %>% table()

tasks %>% 
  arrange(c,p) %>% 
  select(-c, -p) %>% 
  kable() %>% 
  kable_styling() %>% 
  group_rows(index = setNames(categories,
                              paste0("$\\", names(categories), "$"))

articles.title: writeflow
articles.description: Workflow for writing across the manuscript.
articles.contents:
hide

# packages used 
library(tidyverse)
library(kableExtra)

replace_na <- function(text) {
  if_else(is.na(text), "", text)
}

map_na <- function(vector_text) {
  map_chr(as.character(vector_text), replace_na)
}

tracker <- read_rds("data/writing_tracker.rds")

tracker[2:ncol(tracker)] <- tracker[2:ncol(tracker)] %>% 
  as.list() %>% 
  map(map_na) %>% 
  as_tibble()

headings <- names(tracker) %>% 
  as.character()

names(tracker) <- 
  names(tracker) %>% str_sub(1, 4)



Three dots for three manuscripts
Instantiate, at the beginning, thereafter turn to writing tracker.
Count completed sections, and estimate how much of the manuscript has been completed. Add three to that and set this as the goal for the day.
Set n = 3.
Randomly select three manuscripts. Randomly select n sections (for each manuscript) from those with the least number of dots in their corresponding row in the writing tracker.


hide

# for example
tracker %>% 
  mutate(# head = rep("x", 3),
         # sent = c("x", "", "x"),
         para = c("x", "", "")) %>% 
  kable() 



ms_s


head


sent


para


sect


ra_1


ra_2


ra_3


ra_4


1






x












2


















3


















Write as separate tasks in bullet journal.
Actioning one of these means attempting to complete one dot: heading, sentence, paragraph, etc.
Cross action as complete when completed, or if the pomodoro runs out. Consider adding subsections to tracker if action incomplete.
If goal is not met for manuscript, set n = goal - number of poms completed for this manuscript. If goal is met, stop and switch to next manuscript. If third manuscript, only continue for fun.
Instantiate writing tracker table
Set three sections before beginning, as any piece of scientific writing will have an introduction, motivating content, content section, doing the science, and conclusion of content’s findings.


hide

tracker %>% 
  kable() 



ms_s


head


sent


para


sect


ra_1


ra_2


ra_3


ra_4


1


















2


















3
